newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PROFIT-TAKING CREEPS INTO AFRIBRAND.
newsitem.headline: PROFIT-TAKING CREEPS INTO AFRIBRAND.

text.p: Profit-taking knocked the surge in newly-listed Afribrand Ltd on Monday after the firm's successful flotation last week, dealers said.
The stock listed at 100 cents but quickly roared higher and was further boosted when the firm issued a cautionary statement saying it was in talks on possible deals.
"Some guys are just cashing in," one dealer said.
The firm's stock dropped to a day low of 264 cents, but recovered some ground by 0745 GMT to stand unchanged at 280 cents.
However, dealers said there was still a lot of firm market demand for the stock.

Stephen Weir, Afribrand's chief executive, last week declined to say how many possible purchases the lower-income confectionary to snacks firm was eyeing, but squashed market rumours that it could be as many as 20.
He said it was hoped that discussions would be finalised in the next couple of weeks.
"We had one or two discussions and then the prospectus came out and then we had to stop. We are bringing our discussions back again," he said.
